6. POSTAL CHARGES, Stations belonging to the Network are now billed every quarter
for postage charges. The amount that a station is billed depends, of course,
upon the number of tapes ordered and the station*s distance from the Network
Headquarters, As reported elsewhere, the Association Headquarters has been work¬
ing to have educational tapes so classified in postal law that they may be billed
at a more equitable rate# The postal-charge billings have been instituted as
part of the Network*s effort to maintain itself without outside support#
7. NETWORK OUTPUT. Well over a thousand tapes are being mass-duplicated and indi¬
vidually dubbed each week# Since the middle of September, a minimum of twenty-
five master-tapes have been mass-duplicated each week, and we are using every
tape available. The Network has tried very hard to emphasize individualized
service during the past year, but requests for special single dubs and programs
several months old have made the regular work at times most difficult. Again,
the Network Headquarters requests that orders for new series be returned before
deadlines# In spite of our continuing need for tape, we would actually prefer
stations to order possibly unwanted series and later cancel their orders than
to order series after deadlines and request programs already distributed# We
are even shorter on time than on tape.
8. PROGRAMMING. The submission of the much desired quarter-hour programs has been
encouraged with good results, but once again the supply of these short programs
has dropped off. We hope you will take this as your cue to submit a series of
quarter-hour programs to the Network# BBC series are once again available from
Network Headquarters, after being distributed on a "bicycle-leg” system from the
BBC office in New York for the last several years. The programs are now being.
shipped directly to the stations from Urbana; they are not being bicycled. This
makes a wealth of fine material more immediately available to our member stations.
9# SURVEYS. The Network Headquarters has sent out two questionnaires for the Net¬
work School Committee and one questionnaire of its own on distribution. The
results of this latter survey have already been reported, but we would like to
repeat here that we have found the survey most useful* Two of the most import¬
ant findings were confirmations of things we were already fairly certain of: the
Network membership as a whole prefers a four-season system, and it prefers short¬
er programs, as noted in the paragraphs above. Within the range of the mate¬
rial available, the Network Headquarters has done all it could to comply with
these preferences. Of course the acceptance of any programs for the Network
depends on the various Network committees* judgment of the individual series*
worth for Network distribution.
10. SCHOOL PROGRAM WORK. The Network Manager has had four formal meetings with vpi-
ous members of the Network School Committee since the last NAEB Convention. Two
of these meetings were held in Urbana, one in Columbus, and one in Chicago. As
previously reported, these meetings have resulted in a new method of handling in-
school programs. The somewhat painful period of change-over to the new system
is about complete, and the new procedure will be followed hereafter. Very brief¬
ly the new system works like this: In-school series will be offered in the late
fall or winter and distributed twice. The first time, in the spring, they will
be distributed in packages of complete series at a rate of one series a month#
The second time, the following fall, all the series will be distributed with
the general program offering, a reel from each series every couple of weeks#
